Chat History is off for this browser.
When history is turned off, new chats on this browser won't appear in your history on any of your devices, be used to train our models, or stored for longer than 30 days. This setting does not sync across browsers or devices. Learn more

ChatGPT 3.5
You
@media screen and (max-width: 768px) { .grid2, .grid3, .grid { grid-template-columns: repeat(2, 1fr); } .back { background-position: center; padding-top: 50%; height: 80vh; } }explain
ChatGPT

This CSS code snippet is a media query targeting screens with a maximum width of 768 pixels, typically used for styling web content on smaller devices like tablets and mobile phones.

Let's break down the code:

css
@media screen and (max-width: 768px) {

This line starts a media query that applies styles only when the screen width is 768 pixels or less.

css
  .grid2,
  .grid3,
  .grid {
    grid-template-columns: repeat(2, 1fr);
  }

This part of the code targets elements with the classes .grid2, .grid3, and .grid. It sets the grid template columns property to create a grid layout with two columns, each occupying an equal fraction of available space (1fr).

css
  .back {
    background-position: center;
    padding-top: 50%;
    height: 80vh;
  }

Here, the .back class is targeted, and the following styles are applied:

  • background-position: center;: This centers the background image within its container.
  • padding-top: 50%;: This creates vertical padding at the top of the element, making its height 50% of its parent container's width. This is often used to maintain the aspect ratio of an element, such as an image or video.
  • height: 80vh;: This sets the height of the element to 80% of the viewport height (vh), ensuring that it occupies a significant portion of the screen.

Overall, this media query adjusts the layout and styling of elements with the specified classes to improve the user experience on smaller screens, such as tablets and mobile devices.

You
// import React, { useEffect, useState } from 'react' // import { ZIMKitManager , Common } from '@zegocloud/zimkit-react'; // import '@zegocloud/zimkit-react/index.css' // import { APP_ID, APP_SECRET } from './constant'; // const id = Math.floor(Math.random()*1000) // const Chatfinal = ()=> { // const [state , setState ] = useState( // { // appConfig: { // appID: APP_ID, // serverSecret : APP_SECRET, // }, // userInfo: { // userID : Saima${id}, // userName: Saima${id}, // userAvatarUrl:'', // }, // } // ) // useEffect (() => { // const init = async () => { // const zimKit = new ZIMKitManager(); // const token = zimKit.generateKitTokenForTest( // state.appConfig.appID, // state.appConfig.serverSecret, // state.userInfo.userID // ); // await zimKit.init(state.appConfig.appID) // await zimKit.connectUser(state.userInfo, token); // }; // init(); // } , []); // return ( // <div> // welcome back {state.userInfo.userID} // <Common></Common> // </div> // ) // } // export default Chatfinal import React, { useEffect, useState, useRef } from 'react'; import { ZIMKitManager, Common } from '@zegocloud/zimkit-react'; import '@zegocloud/zimkit-react/index.css'; import { APP_ID, APP_SECRET } from './constant'; const Chatfinal = () => { window.addEventListener('unhandledrejection', event => { console.error(Unhandled rejection (promise: ${event.promise}, reason: ${event.reason}).); }); const [userInfo, setUserInfo] = useState({ userID: Saima${Math.floor(Math.random() * 1000)}, userName: Saima${Math.floor(Math.random() * 1000)}, userAvatarUrl: '', }); // Using a ref to hold the zimKit instance so it persists across renders but doesn't cause re-renders const zimKitRef = useRef(null); useEffect(() => { const init = async () => { try { const zimKit = new ZIMKitManager(); const token = await zimKit.generateKitTokenForTest(APP_ID, APP_SECRET, userInfo.userID); // Ensure this is awaited if asynchronous await zimKit.init(APP_ID); await zimKit.connectUser(userInfo, token); zimKitRef.current = zimKit; } catch (error) { console.error('Error during ZIM initialization:', error); } }; init(); }, [userInfo.userID]); // Adjust dependencies as needed // Re-run the effect if userID changes // Function to send a message const sendMessage = async (messageContent, destination, messageType) => { if (!zimKitRef.current) { console.error('ZIMKit instance is not initialized.'); return; } try { const messagePayload = { content: messageContent, destination: destination, type: messageType, }; const response = await zimKitRef.current.sendMessage(messagePayload); console.log('Message sent successfully:', response); } catch (error) { console.error('Error sending message:', error); } }; // Example usage of sendMessage (this could be triggered by a user action like submitting a form) // sendMessage('Hello, World!', 'destinationUserID', 'peer'); return ( <div> Welcome back {userInfo.userID} <Common /> {/* You might want to add a UI here to compose and send messages */} </div> ); }; export default Chatfinal;whats the error
ChatGPT

The error in your code appears to be in the following line:

javascript
console.error(Unhandled rejection (promise: ${event.promise}, reason: ${event.reason}).);

Here, you're trying to log an error message, but the template literal syntax (${}) is not correctly enclosed within backticks (`). Also, you have a period (.) outside the string literal, which is causing a syntax error.

To fix this error, you need to properly enclose the error message within backticks and ensure the template literals are correctly formatted. Here's the corrected line:

javascript
console.error(`Unhandled rejection (promise: ${event.promise}, reason: ${event.reason}).`);

This way, the error message will be correctly formatted, and the syntax error will be resolved.

You
import React, { useEffect, useState, useRef } from 'react'; import { ZIMKitManager, Common } from '@zegocloud/zimkit-react'; import '@zegocloud/zimkit-react/index.css'; import { APP_ID, APP_SECRET } from './constant'; const Chatfinal = () => { window.addEventListener('unhandledrejection', event => { console.error(`Unhandled rejection (promise: ${event.promise}, reason: ${event.reason}).`); }); const [userInfo, setUserInfo] = useState({ userID: Saima${Math.floor(Math.random() * 1000)}, userName: Saima${Math.floor(Math.random() * 1000)}, userAvatarUrl: '', }); // Using a ref to hold the zimKit instance so it persists across renders but doesn't cause re-renders const zimKitRef = useRef(null); useEffect(() => { const init = async () => { try { const zimKit = new ZIMKitManager(); const token = await zimKit.generateKitTokenForTest(APP_ID, APP_SECRET, userInfo.userID); // Ensure this is awaited if asynchronous await zimKit.init(APP_ID); await zimKit.connectUser(userInfo, token); zimKitRef.current = zimKit; } catch (error) { console.error('Error during ZIM initialization:', error); } }; init(); }, [userInfo.userID]); // Adjust dependencies as needed // Re-run the effect if userID changes // Function to send a message const sendMessage = async (messageContent, destination, messageType) => { if (!zimKitRef.current) { console.error('ZIMKit instance is not initialized.'); return; } try { const messagePayload = { content: messageContent, destination: destination, type: messageType, }; const response = await zimKitRef.current.sendMessage(messagePayload); console.log('Message sent successfully:', response); } catch (error) { console.error('Error sending message:', error); } }; // Example usage of sendMessage (this could be triggered by a user action like submitting a form) // sendMessage('Hello, World!', 'destinationUserID', 'peer'); return ( <div> Welcome back {userInfo.userID} <Common /> {/* You might want to add a UI here to compose and send messages */} </div> ); }; export default Chatfinal;
ChatGPT

Your code looks mostly fine, but there are a few potential issues:

  1. Random User ID and Name: Generating random user IDs and names within the state initialization might not be the best approach, especially if the component re-renders. It's better to generate them only once when the component mounts. You can use useEffect with an empty dependency array to achieve this.

  2. Error Handling: While you handle errors during ZIMKit initialization, you might want to add error handling for other asynchronous operations like generating the token or sending messages.

  3. Sending Messages: You've defined the sendMessage function, but it's not used in the current implementation. You might want to integrate it into your component logic to send messages when needed.

Here's a revised version of your code with the mentioned improvements:

javascript
import React, { useEffect, useState, useRef } from 'react';
import { ZIMKitManager, Common } from '@zegocloud/zimkit-react';
import '@zegocloud/zimkit-react/index.css';
import { APP_ID, APP_SECRET } from './constant';

const Chatfinal = () => {
    const [userInfo, setUserInfo] = useState({
        userID: '',
        userName: '',
        userAvatarUrl: '',
    });

    const zimKitRef = useRef(null);

    useEffect(() => {
        const generateUserInfo = () => {
            const id = Math.floor(Math.random() * 1000);
            setUserInfo({
                userID: `Saima${id}`,
                userName: `Saima${id}`,
                userAvatarUrl: '',
            });
        };

        generateUserInfo();
    }, []);

    useEffect(() => {
        const init = async () => {
            try {
                const zimKit = new ZIMKitManager();
                const token = await zimKit.generateKitTokenForTest(APP_ID, APP_SECRET, userInfo.userID);
                await zimKit.init(APP_ID);
                await zimKit.connectUser(userInfo, token);

                zimKitRef.current = zimKit;
            } catch (error) {
                console.error('Error during ZIM initialization:', error);
            }
        };

        if (userInfo.userID !== '') {
            init();
        }
    }, [userInfo.userID]);

    const sendMessage = async (messageContent, destination, messageType) => {
        if (!zimKitRef.current) {
            console.error('ZIMKit instance is not initialized.');
            return;
        }

        try {
            const messagePayload = {
                content: messageContent,
                destination: destination,
                type: messageType,
            };

            const response = await zimKitRef.current.sendMessage(messagePayload);
            console.log('Message sent successfully:', response);
        } catch (error) {
            console.error('Error sending message:', error);
        }
    };

    return (
        <div>
            Welcome back {userInfo.userID}
            <Common />
            {/* Add UI components for composing and sending messages */}
        </div>
    );
};

export default Chatfinal;

In this version, I've separated the generation of user info into its own useEffect hook to ensure it's only executed once when the component mounts. I've also added basic error handling for the sendMessage function and adjusted the dependencies of the useEffect hooks. Finally, remember to integrate the sendMessage function into your component's UI or logic to actually send messages.

You
Unknown promise rejection reason at handleError (http://localhost:3000/static/js/bundle.js:251504:58) at http://localhost:3000/static/js/bundle.js:251527:7
ChatGPT

The error message "Unknown promise rejection reason" suggests that there's an unhandled promise rejection somewhere in your code. This usually means that a promise was rejected (i.e., encountered an error) but no .catch() handler was provided to handle the rejection.

In your case, the error likely occurs within the asynchronous operations of ZIMKit initialization or message sending. To diagnose and fix this issue, you can do the following:

  1. Error Handling: Ensure that you properly handle errors for all asynchronous operations, such as generating the token, initializing ZIMKit, and sending messages. You can add try-catch blocks or use .catch() handlers to catch and handle errors.

  2. Logging: Add logging statements to pinpoint where the error is occurring. You can log the error object itself to get more information about the error.

  3. Debugging: Debug your code using browser developer tools or debugging tools provided by your IDE. This can help you step through your code and identify where the promise rejection is happening.

Here's an example of how you can improve error handling in your code:

javascript
useEffect(() => {
    const init = async () => {
        try {
            const zimKit = new ZIMKitManager();
            const token = await zimKit.generateKitTokenForTest(APP_ID, APP_SECRET, userInfo.userID);
            await zimKit.init(APP_ID);
            await zimKit.connectUser(userInfo, token);

            zimKitRef.current = zimKit;
        } catch (error) {
            console.error('Error during ZIM initialization:', error);
        }
    };

    if (userInfo.userID !== '') {
        init().catch(error => console.error('Error initializing ZIMKit:', error));
    }
}, [userInfo.userID]);

const sendMessage = async (messageContent, destination, messageType) => {
    if (!zimKitRef.current) {
        console.error('ZIMKit instance is not initialized.');
        return;
    }

    try {
        const messagePayload = {
            content: messageContent,
            destination: destination,
            type: messageType,
        };

        const response = await zimKitRef.current.sendMessage(messagePayload);
        console.log('Message sent successfully:', response);
    } catch (error) {
        console.error('Error sending message:', error);
    }
};

By adding try-catch blocks and .catch() handlers, you can properly handle errors and prevent unhandled promise rejections. Additionally, logging errors with console.error() provides useful information for debugging.

You
K.getInstance(...).zim.sendPeerMessage is not a function TypeError: K.getInstance(...).zim.sendPeerMessage is not a function
ChatGPT

The error message "K.getInstance(...).zim.sendPeerMessage is not a function" indicates that there is an attempt to call the sendPeerMessage function on an object that does not have this function defined.

To address this issue:

  1. Verify Function Existence: Ensure that the sendPeerMessage function is indeed available and correctly defined within the zim object or any object returned by K.getInstance().

  2. Check Initialization: Make sure that the ZIMKit instance (zimKit) is properly initialized before attempting to call the sendPeerMessage function. It's possible that the initialization process might not have completed successfully, leading to missing or incomplete functionality.

  3. Review Documentation: Refer to the documentation of ZIMKit or the library you're using to understand how to correctly send peer messages. Make sure you're using the correct method and following the proper usage guidelines.

  4. Debugging: Debug your code to trace the execution flow and identify where the error occurs. You can use logging statements or debugging tools to inspect the objects and their properties/methods at runtime.

Here's an example of how you might revise your code to handle the error:

javascript
const sendMessage = async (messageContent, destination, messageType) => {
    if (!zimKitRef.current || !zimKitRef.current.zim || typeof zimKitRef.current.zim.sendPeerMessage !== 'function') {
        console.error('ZIMKit instance or sendPeerMessage function is not available.');
        return;
    }

    try {
        const messagePayload = {
            content: messageContent,
            destination: destination,
            type: messageType,
        };

        const response = await zimKitRef.current.zim.sendPeerMessage(messagePayload);
        console.log('Message sent successfully:', response);
    } catch (error) {
        console.error('Error sending message:', error);
    }
};

In this revised code, we added additional checks to ensure that zimKitRef.current and zimKitRef.current.zim.sendPeerMessage are both available and of the expected type before attempting to call the function. This helps prevent errors related to missing or undefined functions.

You
import { useState } from 'react'; import Calendar from 'react-calendar'; import 'react-calendar/dist/Calendar.css'; type ValuePiece = Date | null; type Value = ValuePiece | [ValuePiece, ValuePiece]; const CalendarM = () => { const [value, onChange] = useState<Value>(new Date()); return ( <div> <Calendar onChange={onChange} value={value} /> </div> ) } export default CalendarM
ChatGPT

Your CalendarM component is using the react-calendar package to render a calendar UI component. It allows users to select dates, and the selected date(s) are managed using React state.

Here's a breakdown of your code:

  1. Import statements: You import useState from react and the Calendar component from react-calendar. You also import the default styles for the calendar component.

  2. Type definitions: You define two types - ValuePiece and Value. ValuePiece can be either a Date object or null, and Value can be either a single ValuePiece or an array of two ValuePiece objects. This is used to define the state type for the selected date(s).

  3. CalendarM component: This is a functional component. It initializes state using the useState hook. The value state holds the selected date(s), and onChange is a function to update the selected date(s) when the user interacts with the calendar.

  4. Inside the component's JSX: The Calendar component is rendered, and its onChange and value props are set to the state values (onChange function and value state, respectively).

Overall, this component provides a simple calendar UI that users can interact with to select date(s), and it demonstrates the usage of React state to manage the selected date(s).

You
import { useState } from 'react'; import Calendar from 'react-calendar'; import 'react-calendar/dist/Calendar.css'; type ValuePiece = Date | null; type Value = ValuePiece | [ValuePiece, ValuePiece]; const CalendarM = () => { const [value, onChange] = useState<Value>(new Date()); return ( <div> <Calendar onChange={onChange} value={value} /> </div> ) } export default CalendarMgetting errors
ChatGPT

It seems there might be errors occurring when you're using the useState hook with the Value type. Let's troubleshoot and see if we can resolve them:

  1. Type Error: One potential issue is that useState expects an initial state value of type Value, but you're providing it with a Date object (new Date()). To fix this, you can initialize the state with null or an array of two null values, depending on how you intend to use the calendar.

  2. ValuePiece Usage: Ensure that the ValuePiece and Value types are properly defined and being used correctly. If they are defined elsewhere in your codebase, ensure that they are imported correctly or declared in the same file.

  3. React Calendar Props: Make sure that the onChange function and value state are correctly passed to the Calendar component as props. Check if the Calendar component expects these props in the correct format.

Let's make some adjustments to address these potential issues:

javascript
import React, { useState } from 'react';
import Calendar from 'react-calendar';
import 'react-calendar/dist/Calendar.css';

// Define types
type ValuePiece = Date | null;
type Value = ValuePiece | [ValuePiece, ValuePiece];

const CalendarM = () => {
    // Initialize state with null or an array of null values
    const [value, onChange] = useState<Value>(null); // Or [null, null] if using range selection

    return (
        <div>
            {/* Pass onChange and value props to Calendar component */}
            <Calendar onChange={onChange} value={value} />
        </div>
    );
};

export default CalendarM;

In this adjusted code:

  • I've initialized the value state with null since it's common to start with no selected date. If you intend to use range selection, you can initialize it with [null, null].
  • I've ensured that the onChange function and value state are correctly passed to the Calendar component as props.

Try these adjustments and see if they resolve the errors you're encountering. If you're still having issues, please provide more details about the specific errors you're seeing.

ChatGPT

If you're encountering an error stating that "value is not defined", it may be because the value variable is not properly imported or defined. However, in your provided code, value is indeed defined within the component using the useState hook.

The error might be occurring due to a naming conflict or scoping issue elsewhere in your codebase. To troubleshoot this issue, here are some steps you can take:

  1. Check Variable Scope: Ensure that there are no other variables named value within the scope of your component or its parent components. Sometimes, naming conflicts can lead to such errors.

  2. Inspect Imports: Double-check the imports at the top of your file. Make sure that the useState function and the Calendar component are imported correctly from the react and react-calendar packages, respectively.

  3. Check for Typos: Verify that there are no typos or misspellings in the variable names. Sometimes, small errors like this can cause unexpected issues.

  4. Inspect Dependencies: If your component relies on other components or context providers, ensure that they are properly imported and initialized.

Here's your code with comments pointing out where value is defined:

javascript
import React, { useState } from 'react';
import Calendar from 'react-calendar';
import 'react-calendar/dist/Calendar.css';

// Define types
type ValuePiece = Date | null;
type Value = ValuePiece | [ValuePiece, ValuePiece];

const CalendarM = () => {
    // 'value' is defined here using the useState hook
    const [value, onChange] = useState<Value>(null); // Or [null, null] if using range selection

    return (
        <div>
            {/* Pass onChange and value props to Calendar component */}
            <Calendar onChange={onChange} value={value} />
        </div>
    );
};

export default CalendarM;

If the error persists after ensuring that value is correctly defined and imported, please provide more details about the specific error message and any relevant code snippets for further assistance.

You
src\ALcomponents\Pages\Calendar.jsx Line 56:2: 'ValuePiece' is not defined no-undef Line 57:2: 'Value' is not defined no-undef Line 57:10: 'ValuePiece' is not defined no-undef Line 57:24: 'ValuePiece' is not defined no-undef Line 57:36: 'ValuePiece' is not defined no-undef Line 61:40: 'Value' is not defined no-undef Search for the keywords to learn more about each errormport React, { useState } from 'react'; import Calendar from 'react-calendar'; import 'react-calendar/dist/Calendar.css'; // Define types ValuePiece = Date | null; Value = ValuePiece | [ValuePiece, ValuePiece]; const CalendarM = () => { // 'value' is defined here using the useState hook const [value, onChange] = useState<Value>(null); // Or [null, null] if using range selection return ( <div> {/* Pass onChange and value props to Calendar component */} <Calendar onChange={onChange} value={value} /> </div> ); };
ChatGPT

It appears that you're encountering TypeScript-related errors in your code due to the undefined types ValuePiece and Value. To resolve these errors, you need to properly define these types in your TypeScript code.

Here's how you can fix the errors:

typescript
import React, { useState } from 'react';
import Calendar from 'react-calendar';
import 'react-calendar/dist/Calendar.css';

// Define types
type ValuePiece = Date | null;
type Value = ValuePiece | [ValuePiece, ValuePiece]; // Define type 'Value' based on 'ValuePiece'

const CalendarM = () => {
    // 'value' is defined here using the useState hook
    const [value, onChange] = useState<Value>(null); // Or [null, null] if using range selection

    return (
        <div>
            {/* Pass onChange and value props to Calendar component */}
            <Calendar onChange={onChange} value={value as Date | Date[]} /> {/* Cast 'value' to 'Date' or 'Date[]' */}
        </div>
    );
};

export default CalendarM;

In this code:

  • I've defined the ValuePiece and Value types using the type keyword.
  • I've added the type keyword before defining the types to ensure they are recognized by TypeScript.
  • I've adjusted the JSX syntax to cast value as Date | Date[] to satisfy the TypeScript compiler.

With these changes, the TypeScript compiler should no longer report errors related to undefined types ValuePiece and Value.

You
Value is not defined ReferenceError: Value is not defined at CalendarM (http://localhost:3000/main.7d829b61960c8e3090c8.hot-update.js:81:75) at renderWithHooks (http://localhost:3000/static/js/bundle.js:135404:22) at mountIndeterminateComponent (http://localhost:3000/static/js/bundle.js:138688:17) at beginWork (http://localhost:3000/static/js/bundle.js:139984:20) at HTMLUnknownElement.callCallback (http://localhost:3000/static/js/bundle.js:125000:18) at Object.invokeGuardedCallbackDev (http://localhost:3000/static/js/bundle.js:125044:20) at invokeGuardedCallback (http://localhost:3000/static/js/bundle.js:125101:35) at beginWork$1 (http://localhost:3000/static/js/bundle.js:144965:11) at performUnitOfWork (http://localhost:3000/static/js/bundle.js:144213:16) at workLoopSync (http://localhost:3000/static/js/bundle.js:144136:9)
ChatGPT

It seems there was a misunderstanding regarding TypeScript usage. Your project appears to be using TypeScript, and the error message indicates that it's expecting a variable named Value, which is not defined.

Here's the corrected TypeScript code for your component:

typescript
import React, { useState } from 'react';
import Calendar from 'react-calendar';
import 'react-calendar/dist/Calendar.css';

// Define types
type ValuePiece = Date | null;
type Value = ValuePiece | [ValuePiece, ValuePiece];

const CalendarM: React.FC = () => {
    // Initialize state with null or an array of null values
    const [value, onChange] = useState<Value>(null);

    return (
        <div>
            {/* Pass onChange and value props to Calendar component */}
            <Calendar onChange={onChange} value={value as Date | Date[]} />
        </div>
    );
};

export default CalendarM;

In TypeScript, when you define a type, you can use it directly in your component. However, make sure to import React if you're using JSX syntax.

The error occurred because TypeScript expected a variable named Value to be defined, but it wasn't found in your code. By defining the types ValuePiece and Value and using them correctly in the component, you should resolve the error.

You
import React from "react"; import Calendar from "react-calendar"; import "react-calendar/dist/Calendar.css"; const CalendarM = () => { return ( <div> <Calendar /> </div> ); }; export default CalendarM;i want advance event schedular calendar full code
ChatGPT

To create an advanced event scheduler calendar, you'll need to integrate additional functionalities such as event handling, customization, and possibly backend integration for storing and retrieving events. Below is a basic example of an advanced event scheduler calendar using react-calendar with event handling and basic customization:

jsx
import React, { useState } from "react";
import Calendar from "react-calendar";
import "react-calendar/dist/Calendar.css";

const CalendarM = () => {
  const [date, setDate] = useState(new Date());
  const [events, setEvents] = useState([]);

  const handleDateChange = (date) => {
    setDate(date);
  };

  const handleEventClick = (event) => {
    // Handle event click (e.g., show event details)
    console.log("Event clicked:", event);
  };

  const handleAddEvent = () => {
    // Example function to add a new event
    const newEvent = {
      id: Math.random(),
      date: date,
      title: "New Event",
      description: "Description of the event",
    };
    setEvents([...events, newEvent]);
  };

  return (
    <div>
      <div>
        <button onClick={handleAddEvent}>Add Event</button>
      </div>
      <div>
        <Calendar
          onChange={handleDateChange}
          value={date}
          onClickDay={handleEventClick}
          tileContent={({ date }) => {
            // Customize tile content (e.g., display event indicators)
            const eventForDay = events.find((event) => event.date.toDateString() === date.toDateString());
            return eventForDay ? <span style={{ backgroundColor: "red", borderRadius: "50%", display: "block", width: "8px", height: "8px" }}></span> : null;
          }}
        />
      </div>
      <div>
        {/* Render event list */}
        <h2>Events for {date.toDateString()}:</h2>
        <ul>
          {events.map((event) => (
            <li key={event.id}>
              <strong>{event.title}</strong> - {event.description}
            </li>
          ))}
        </ul>
      </div>
    </div>
  );
};

export default CalendarM;

This code provides a basic event scheduler calendar with the following features:

  • Displaying a calendar using react-calendar.
  • Handling date changes with the onChange function.
  • Adding events to specific dates and displaying them.
  • Customizing the tile content of the calendar to indicate dates with events.
  • Handling event clicks on calendar tiles.
  • Displaying a list of events for the selected date.

You can expand upon this code by adding more advanced features such as:

  • Drag and drop functionality to move events.
  • Editing and deleting events.
  • Backend integration to store events persistently.
  • Additional customization options for events and calendar appearance.

Keep in mind that the provided code is a starting point, and you may need to customize it further based on your specific requirements.

You

// import { createElement } from '@syncfusion/ej2-base'; // import { DropDownList } from '@syncfusion/ej2-dropdowns'; // // import { scheduleData } from './datasource'; // const CalendarM = () => { // const eventSettings = {}; // formElement.firstChild.insertBefore(row, formElement.firstChild.firstChild); // let container = createElement('div', { className: 'custom-field-container' }); // let inputEle = createElement('input', { // className: 'e-field', attrs: { name: 'EventType' } // }); // container.appendChild(inputEle); // row.appendChild(container); // let drowDownList = new DropDownList({ // dataSource: [ // { text: 'Public Event', value: 'public-event' }, // { text: 'Maintenance', value: 'maintenance' }, // { text: 'Commercial Event', value: 'commercial-event' }, // { text: 'Family Event', value: 'family-event' } // ], // fields: { text: 'text', value: 'value' }, // value: args.data.EventType, // floatLabelType: 'Always', placeholder: 'Event Type' // }); // drowDownList.appendTo(inputEle); // inputEle.setAttribute('name', 'EventType'); // } // } // } // return (<ScheduleComponent width='100%' height='550px' selectedDate={new Date(2018, 1, 15)} eventSettings={eventSettings} popupOpen={onPopupOpen}> // <ViewsDirective> // <ViewDirective option='Day' /> // <ViewDirective option='Week' /> // <ViewDirective option='WorkWeek' /> // <ViewDirective option='Month' /> // </ViewsDirective> // <Inject services={[Day, Week, WorkWeek, Month]} /> // </ScheduleComponent>); // } // ; // export default CalendarMlike this
ChatGPT

It seems like you're trying to use the Syncfusion React Scheduler (@syncfusion/ej2-react-schedule) to create an event scheduler calendar. Your code looks mostly correct, but it's commented out, and there are some adjustments that need to be made to ensure it functions properly. Here's the code with some explanations and adjustments:

javascript
import React from 'react';
import { ScheduleComponent, ViewsDirective, ViewDirective, Day, Week, WorkWeek, Month, Inject } from '@syncfusion/ej2-react-schedule';
import { createElement } from '@syncfusion/ej2-base';
import { DropDownList } from '@syncfusion/ej2-dropdowns';

const CalendarM = () => {
    const eventSettings = {};

    const onPopupOpen = (args) => {
        if (args.type === 'Editor') {
            if (!args.element.querySelector('.custom-field-row')) {
                let row = createElement('div', { className: 'custom-field-row' });
                let formElement = args.element.querySelector('.e-schedule-form');
                formElement.firstChild.insertBefore(row, formElement.firstChild.firstChild);
                let container = createElement('div', { className: 'custom-field-container' });
                let inputEle = createElement('input', {
                    className: 'e-field', attrs: { name: 'EventType' }
                });
                container.appendChild(inputEle);
                row.appendChild(container);
                let drowDownList = new DropDownList({
                    dataSource: [
                        { text: 'Public Event', value: 'public-event' },
                        { text: 'Maintenance', value: 'maintenance' },
                        { text: 'Commercial Event', value: 'commercial-event' },
                        { text: 'Family Event', value: 'family-event' }
                    ],
                    fields: { text: 'text', value: 'value' },
                    value: args.data.EventType,
                    floatLabelType: 'Always', placeholder: 'Event Type'
                });
                drowDownList.appendTo(inputEle);
                inputEle.setAttribute('name', 'EventType');
            }
        }
    }

    return (
        <ScheduleComponent width='100%' height='550px' selectedDate={new Date(2018, 1, 15)} eventSettings={eventSettings} popupOpen={onPopupOpen}>
            <ViewsDirective>
                <ViewDirective option='Day' />
                <ViewDirective option='Week' />
                <ViewDirective option='WorkWeek' />
                <ViewDirective option='Month' />
            </ViewsDirective>
            <Inject services={[Day, Week, WorkWeek, Month]} />
        </ScheduleComponent>
    );
};

export default CalendarM;

Here's what's happening in the code:

  1. The ScheduleComponent is the main component for the Scheduler. It defines the width, height, selected date, event settings, and a callback function onPopupOpen to handle popup opening events.

  2. In the onPopupOpen function, a custom field for event type is added to the editor popup. This is achieved by creating DOM elements dynamically using createElement from Syncfusion's utilities.

  3. The ViewsDirective and ViewDirective components are used to define the views available in the Scheduler (Day, Week, WorkWeek, Month).

  4. The Inject component is used to inject the required Scheduler services (Day, Week, WorkWeek, Month) into the Scheduler component.

Make sure you have properly installed and configured Syncfusion's dependencies (@syncfusion/ej2-react-schedule, @syncfusion/ej2-base, @syncfusion/ej2-dropdowns) in your project for this code to work. Additionally, adjust the event settings and other configurations as per your requirements.

You

// const onPopupOpen = (args) => { // if (args.type === 'Editor') { // if (!args.element.querySelector('.custom-field-row')) { // let row = createElement('div', { className: 'custom-field-row' }); // let formElement = args.element.querySelector('.e-schedule-form'); // formElement.firstChild.insertBefore(row, formElement.firstChild.firstChild); // let container = createElement('div', { className: 'custom-field-container' }); // let inputEle = createElement('input', { // className: 'e-field', attrs: { name: 'EventType' } // }); // container.appendChild(inputEle); // row.appendChild(container); // let drowDownList = new DropDownList({ // dataSource: [ // { text: 'Public Event', value: 'public-event' }, // { text: 'Maintenance', value: 'maintenance' }, // { text: 'Commercial Event', value: 'commercial-event' }, // { text: 'Family Event', value: 'family-event' } // ], // fields: { text: 'text', value: 'value' }, // value: args.data.EventType, // floatLabelType: 'Always', placeholder: 'Event Type' // }); // drowDownList.appendTo(inputEle); // inputEle.setAttribute('name', 'EventType'); // } // } // } // return (<ScheduleComponent width='100%' height='550px' selectedDate={new Date(2018, 1, 15)} eventSettings={eventSettings} popupOpen={onPopupOpen}> // <ViewsDirective> // <ViewDirective option='Day' /> // <ViewDirective option='Week' /> // <ViewDirective option='WorkWeek' /> // <ViewDirective option='Month' /> // </ViewsDirective> // <Inject services={[Day, Week, WorkWeek, Month]} /> // </ScheduleComponent>); // } // ; // export default CalendarMi want this kinda event schedular calendar butnot the syncfusion made one for me full code
ChatGPT

Here's an example of a simple event scheduler calendar without using Syncfusion:

jsx
import React, { useState } from 'react';

const CalendarM = () => {
    const [events, setEvents] = useState([]);
    const [eventType, setEventType] = useState('');
    const [selectedDate, setSelectedDate] = useState(new Date());

    const handleDateChange = (date) => {
        setSelectedDate(date);
    };

    const handleEventTypeChange = (event) => {
        setEventType(event.target.value);
    };

    const handleAddEvent = () => {
        const newEvent = {
            id: events.length + 1,
            date: selectedDate,
            type: eventType,
        };
        setEvents([...events, newEvent]);
        setEventType(''); // Reset eventType after adding event
    };

    return (
        <div>
            <input type="date" value={selectedDate.toISOString().substr(0, 10)} onChange={(e) => handleDateChange(new Date(e.target.value))} />
            <select value={eventType} onChange={handleEventTypeChange}>
                <option value="">Select Event Type</option>
                <option value="Public Event">Public Event</option>
                <option value="Maintenance">Maintenance</option>
                <option value="Commercial Event">Commercial Event</option>
                <option value="Family Event">Family Event</option>
            </select>
            <button onClick={handleAddEvent}>Add Event</button>
            <div>
                <h2>Events for {selectedDate.toDateString()}:</h2>
                <ul>
                    {events.map((event) => (
                        <li key={event.id}>
                            <strong>{event.type}</strong> - {event.date.toLocaleTimeString()}
                        </li>
                    ))}
                </ul>
            </div>
        </div>
    );
};

export default CalendarM;

In this example:

  • The calendar allows the user to select a date and choose an event type from a dropdown.
  • When the user clicks "Add Event", it adds the event with the selected date and type to the list of events displayed below.
  • Each event has an ID, date, and type.
  • The list of events is rendered below the calendar.

This is a simple example and doesn't include advanced features like recurring events or drag-and-drop functionality. You can extend it further according to your requirements.

You
i want the full calendar to be seen horizontal dates and vertically times of the date there is button with add event and then after clicking it the widow open to add the event
ChatGPT

I understand. You want a full calendar view with dates displayed horizontally and times displayed vertically. Here's how you can achieve that:

jsx
import React, { useState } from 'react';

const CalendarM = () => {
    const [events, setEvents] = useState([]);
    const [selectedDate, setSelectedDate] = useState(new Date());
    const [eventType, setEventType] = useState('');
    const [showEventModal, setShowEventModal] = useState(false);

    const handleDateChange = (date) => {
        setSelectedDate(date);
    };

    const handleEventTypeChange = (event) => {
        setEventType(event.target.value);
    };

    const handleAddEvent = () => {
        setShowEventModal(true);
    };

    const handleCloseEventModal = () => {
        setShowEventModal(false);
    };

    const handleSaveEvent = () => {
        const newEvent = {
            date: selectedDate,
            type: eventType,
        };
        setEvents([...events, newEvent]);
        setShowEventModal(false);
        setEventType('');
    };

    return (
        <div>
            <div>
                <input type="date" value={selectedDate.toISOString().substr(0, 10)} onChange={(e) => handleDateChange(new Date(e.target.value))} />
                <select value={eventType} onChange={handleEventTypeChange}>
                    <option value="">Select Event Type</option>
                    <option value="Public Event">Public Event</option>
                    <option value="Maintenance">Maintenance</option>
                    <option value="Commercial Event">Commercial Event</option>
                    <option value="Family Event">Family Event</option>
                </select>
                <button onClick={handleAddEvent}>Add Event</button>
            </div>
            <div style={{ display: 'flex', flexDirection: 'row' }}>
                <div style={{ flex: 1 }}>
                    <h2>Times</h2>
                    {/* Display times vertically */}
                    {Array.from({ length: 24 }, (_, i) => {
                        const time = `${i < 10 ? '0' : ''}${i}:00`;
                        return <div key={time}>{time}</div>;
                    })}
                </div>
                <div style={{ flex: 7 }}>
                    <h2>Calendar</h2>
                    {/* Display dates horizontally */}
                    <table>
                        <thead>
                            <tr>
                                {Array.from({ length: 7 }, (_, i) => {
                                    const date = new Date(selectedDate);
                                    date.setDate(date.getDate() + i);
                                    return <th key={i}>{date.toDateString()}</th>;
                                })}
                            </tr>
                        </thead>
                        <tbody>
                            {/* Display events */}
                            {Array.from({ length: 24 }, (_, i) => (
                                <tr key={i}>
                                    {Array.from({ length: 7 }, (_, j) => {
                                        const date = new Date(selectedDate);
                                        date.setDate(date.getDate() + j);
                                        const event = events.find((e) => e.date.toDateString() === date.toDateString() && e.date.getHours() === i);
                                        return <td key={j}>{event ? event.type : ''}</td>;
                                    })}
                                </tr>
                            ))}
                        </tbody>
                    </table>
                </div>
            </div>
            {showEventModal && (
                <div className="event-modal">
                    <h2>Add Event</h2>
                    <div>
                        <input type="text" placeholder="Event Type" value={eventType} onChange={(e) => setEventType(e.target.value)} />
                    </div>
                    <div>
                        <button onClick={handleSaveEvent}>Save</button>
                        <button onClick={handleCloseEventModal}>Cancel</button>
                    </div>
                </div>
            )}
        </div>
    );
};

export default CalendarM;

In this example:

  • The calendar is displayed with dates horizontally and times vertically.
  • The user can select a date and event type, then click "Add Event" to open a modal window to add the event.
  • Events are displayed in a table format, with times on the left and dates on the top.
  • When an event is added, it's displayed in the corresponding cell based on the date and time.
You
<!doctype html> <html lang="en"> <head> <title>Calendar 04</title> <meta charset="utf-8"> <meta name="viewport" content="width=device-width, initial-scale=1, shrink-to-fit=no"> <link class="container"> <div class="row justify-content-center"> <div class="col-md-6 text-center mb-5"> <h2 class="heading-section">Calendar #04</h2> </div> </div> <div class="row"> <div class="col-md-12"> <div class="content w-100"> <div class="calendar-container"> <div class="calendar"> <div class="year-header"> <span class="left-button fa fa-chevron-left" id="prev"> </span> <span class="day">Mon</td> <td class="day">Tue</td> <td class="day">Wed</td> <td class="day">Thu</td> <td class="day">Fri</td> <td class="day">Sat</td> </table> <div class="frame"> <table class="dates-table w-100"> <tbody class="tbody"> </tbody> </table> </div> <button class="button" id="add-button">Add Event</button> </div> </div> <div class="events-container"> </div> <div class="dialog" id="dialog"> <h2 class="dialog-header"> Add New Event </h2> <form class="form" id="form"> <div class="form-container" align="center"> <label class="form-label" id="valueFromMyButton" for="name">Event name</label> <input class="input" type="text" id="name" maxlength="36"> <label class="form-label" id="valueFromMyButton" for="count">Number of people to invite</label> <input class="input" type="number" id="count" min="0" max="1000000" maxlength="7"> <input type="button" value="Cancel" class="button" id="cancel-button"> <input type="button" value="OK" class="button button-white" id="ok-button"> </div> </form> </div> </div> </div> </div> </div> </section> <script src="js/jquery.min.js"></script> <script src="js/popper.js"></script> <script src="js/bootstrap.min.js"></script> <script src="js/main.js"></script> </body> </html> i want this in react
ChatGPT

To convert the provided HTML code into a React component, you'll need to break down the structure and functionality of the calendar and implement it using React's components and state management. Below is a basic conversion of the provided HTML into a React component:

jsx
import React, { useState } from 'react';
import './Calendar.css'; // Import CSS file

const Calendar = () => {
    // State for managing events
    const [events, setEvents] = useState([]);
    // State for managing the dialog visibility
    const [showDialog, setShowDialog] = useState(false);
    // State for managing the event name input
    const [eventName, setEventName] = useState('');
    // State for managing the number of people input
    const [numberOfPeople, setNumberOfPeople] = useState(0);

    // Function to handle opening the dialog
    const handleAddEvent = () => {
        setShowDialog(true);
    };

    // Function to handle closing the dialog
    const handleCloseDialog = () => {
        setShowDialog(false);
    };

    // Function to handle saving the event
    const handleSaveEvent = () => {
        const newEvent = {
            name: eventName,
            numberOfPeople: numberOfPeople
        };
        setEvents([...events, newEvent]);
        setShowDialog(false);
        // Reset input fields
        setEventName('');
        setNumberOfPeople(0);
    };

    return (
        <div className="container">
            <div className="calendar-container">
                {/* Calendar HTML */}
                {/* Omitted for brevity */}
                <button className="button" onClick={handleAddEvent}>Add Event</button>
            </div>
            {/* Dialog for adding new event */}
            {showDialog && (
                <div className="dialog">
                    <h2 className="dialog-header">Add New Event</h2>
                    <form className="form">
                        <div className="form-container" align="center">
                            <label className="form-label" htmlFor="name">Event name</label>
                            <input className="input" type="text" id="name" value={eventName} onChange={(e) => setEventName(e.target.value)} />
                            <label className="form-label" htmlFor="count">Number of people to invite</label>
                            <input className="input" type="number" id="count" min="0" max="1000000" value={numberOfPeople} onChange={(e) => setNumberOfPeople(e.target.value)} />
                            <button type="button" className="button" onClick={handleCloseDialog}>Cancel</button>
                            <button type="button" className="button button-white" onClick={handleSaveEvent}>OK</button>
                        </div>
                    </form>
                </div>
            )}
        </div>
    );
};

export default Calendar;

In this React component:

  • We're using React hooks (useState) to manage the state for events, dialog visibility, event name, and number of people.
  • The handleAddEvent function sets the showDialog state to true when the "Add Event" button is clicked, which triggers the display of the dialog.
  • The handleCloseDialog function sets the showDialog state to false when the "Cancel" button is clicked, which hides the dialog.
  • The handleSaveEvent function saves the event details entered in the dialog and updates the events state accordingly. It also resets the input fields and hides the dialog.
You

number of people input const [numberOfPeople, setNumberOfPeople] = useState(0); // Function to handle opening the dialog const handleAddEvent = () => { setShowDialog(true); }; // Function to handle closing the dialog const handleCloseDialog = () => { setShowDialog(false); }; // Function to handle saving the event const handleSaveEvent = () => { const newEvent = { name: eventName, numberOfPeople: <td class="month">May</td> <td class="month">Jun</td> <td class="month">Jul</td> <td class="month">Aug</td> <td class="month">Sep</td> <td class="month">Oct</td> <td class="month">Nov</td> <td class="month">Dec</td> </tr> </tbody> </table> <table class="days-table w-100"> <td class="day">Sun</td> <td class="day">Mon</td> <td class="day">Tue</td> <td class="day">Wed</td> <td class="day">Thu</td> <td class="day">Fri</td> <td class="day">Sat</td> </table> <div class="frame"> <table class="dates-table w-100"> <tbody class="tbody"> </tbody> </table> </div> <button class="button" id="add-button">Add Event</button> </div> </div> <div class="events-container"> </div> <div class="dialog" id="dialog"> <h2 class="dialog-header"> Add New Event </h2> <form class="form" id="form"> <div class="form-container" align="center"> <label class="form-label" id="valueFromMyButton" for="name">Event name</label> <input class="input" type="text" id="name" maxlength="36"/> <label class="form-label" id="valueFromMyButton" for="count">Number of people to invite</label> <input class="input" type="number" id="count" min="0" max="1000000" maxlength="7"/> <input type="button" value="Cancel" class="button" id="cancel-button"> <input type="button" value="OK" class="button button-white" id="ok-button"> </div> </form> </div> </div> </div> </div> </div> <button className="button" onClick={handleAddEvent}>Add Event</button> </div> {/* Dialog for adding new event */} {showDialog && ( <div className="dialog"> <h2 className="dialog-header">Add New Event</h2> <form className="form"> <div className="form-container" align="center"> <label className="form-label" htmlFor="name">Event name</label> <input className="input" type="text" id="name" value={eventName} onChange={(e) => setEventName(e.target.value)} /> <label className="form-label" htmlFor="count">Number of people to invite</label> <input className="input" type="number" id="count" min="0" max="1000000" value={numberOfPeople} onChange={(e) => setNumberOfPeople(e.target.value)} /> <button type="button" className="button" onClick={handleCloseDialog}>Cancel</button> <button type="button" className="button button-white" onClick={handleSaveEvent}>OK</button> </div> </form> </div> )} </div> ); }; export default CalendarM;
ChatGPT

Your code is almost there! You have combined the original calendar HTML with the React component. However, you should separate them for better readability and maintainability. Also, you should use className instead of class when writing JSX in React.

Here's the corrected version of your component:

jsx
import React, { useState } from 'react';
import './Calendar.css'; // Import CSS file

const CalendarM = () => {
    // State for managing events
    const [events, setEvents] = useState([]);
    // State for managing the dialog visibility
    const [showDialog, setShowDialog] = useState(false);
    // State for managing the event name input
    const [eventName, setEventName] = useState('');
    // State for managing the number of people input
    const [numberOfPeople, setNumberOfPeople] = useState(0);

    // Function to handle opening the dialog
    const handleAddEvent = () => {
        setShowDialog(true);
    };

    // Function to handle closing the dialog
    const handleCloseDialog = () => {
        setShowDialog(false);
    };

    // Function to handle saving the event
    const handleSaveEvent = () => {
        const newEvent = {
            name: eventName,
            numberOfPeople: numberOfPeople
        };
        setEvents([...events, newEvent]);
        setShowDialog(false);
        // Reset input fields
        setEventName('');
        setNumberOfPeople(0);
    };

    return (
        <div className="container">
            <div className="calendar-container">
                <div className="calendar">
                    <div className="year-header">
                        <span className="left-button fa fa-chevron-left" id="prev"></span>
                        <span className="year" id="label"></span>
                        <span className="right-button fa fa-chevron-right" id="next"></span>
                    </div>
                    <table className="months-table w-100">
                        <tbody>
                            <tr className="months-row">
                                <td className="month">Jan</td>
                                <td className="month">Feb</td>
                                <td className="month">Mar</td>
                                <td className="month">Apr</td>
                                <td className="month">May</td>
                                <td className="month">Jun</td>
                                <td className="month">Jul</td>
                                <td className="month">Aug</td>
                                <td className="month">Sep</td>
                                <td className="month">Oct</td>
                                <td className="month">Nov</td>
                                <td className="month">Dec</td>
                            </tr>
                        </tbody>
                    </table>

                    <table className="days-table w-100">
                        <tbody>
                            <tr>
                                <td className="day">Sun</td>
                                <td className="day">Mon</td>
                                <td className="day">Tue</td>
                                <td className="day">Wed</td>
                                <td className="day">Thu</td>
                                <td className="day">Fri</td>
                                <td className="day">Sat</td>
                            </tr>
                        </tbody>
                    </table>

                    <div className="frame">
                        <table className="dates-table w-100">
                            <tbody className="tbody">
                                {/* Dates will be dynamically generated here */}
                            </tbody>
                        </table>
                    </div>
                    <button className="button" id="add-button" onClick={handleAddEvent}>Add Event</button>
                </div>
            </div>

            {/* Dialog for adding new event */}
            {showDialog && (
                <div className="dialog">
                    <h2 className="dialog-header">Add New Event</h2>
                    <form className="form">
                        <div className="form-container" align="center">
                            <label className="form-label" htmlFor="name">Event name</label>
                            <input className="input" type="text" id="name" value={eventName} onChange={(e) => setEventName(e.target.value)} maxLength="36" />
                            <label className="form-label" htmlFor="count">Number of people to invite</label>
                            <input className="input" type="number" id="count" min="0" max="1000000" value={numberOfPeople} onChange={(e) => setNumberOfPeople(e.target.value)} maxLength="7" />
                            <button type="button" className="button" onClick={handleCloseDialog}>Cancel</button>
                            <button type="button" className="button button-white" onClick={handleSaveEvent}>OK</button>
                        </div>
                    </form>
                </div>
            )}
        </div>
    );
};

export default CalendarM;

Make sure you have the appropriate CSS styles defined in Calendar.css for the calendar and dialog components to display properly.

You
import * as React from 'react'; import { styled } from '@mui/material/styles'; import Paper from '@mui/material/Paper'; import { ViewState } from '@devexpress/dx-react-scheduler'; import { Scheduler, Resources, WeekView, Appointments, AppointmentTooltip, } from '@devexpress/dx-react-scheduler-material-ui'; import Select from '@mui/material/Select'; import MenuItem from '@mui/material/MenuItem'; const PREFIX = 'Demo'; const classes = { container: `${PREFIX}-container`, text: `${PREFIX}-text`, }; const StyledDiv = styled('div')(({ theme }) => ({ [`&.${classes.container}`]: { display: 'flex', marginBottom: theme.spacing(2), justifyContent: 'flex-end', }, [`& .${classes.text}`]: { ...theme.typography.h6, marginRight: theme.spacing(2), }, })); const appointments = [{ title: 'Website Re-Design Plan', startDate: new Date(2018, 5, 25, 12, 35), endDate: new Date(2018, 5, 25, 15, 0), id: 0, members: [1, 3, 5], location: 'Room 1', }, { title: 'Book Flights to San Fran for Sales Trip', startDate: new Date(2018, 5, 26, 12, 35), endDate: new Date(2018, 5, 26, 15, 0), id: 1, members: [2, 4], location: 'Room 2', }, { title: 'Install New Router in Dev Room', startDate: new Date(2018, 5, 27, 12, 35), endDate: new Date(2018, 5, 27, 15, 0), id: 2, members: [3], location: 'Room 3', }, { title: 'Approve Personal Computer Upgrade Plan', startDate: new Date(2018, 5, 28, 12, 35), endDate: new Date(2018, 5, 28, 15, 0), id: 3, members: [4, 1], location: 'Room 4', }, { title: 'Final Budget Review', startDate: new Date(2018, 5, 29, 12, 35), endDate: new Date(2018, 5, 29, 15, 0), id: 4, members: [5, 1, 3], location: 'Room 5', }]; const ResourceSwitcher = ( ({ mainResourceName, onChange, resources, }) => ( <StyledDiv className={classes.container}> <div className={classes.text}> Main resource name: </div> <Select variant="standard" value={mainResourceName} onChange={e => onChange(e.target.value)} > {resources.map(resource => ( <MenuItem key={resource.fieldName} value={resource.fieldName}> {resource.title} </MenuItem> ))} </Select> </StyledDiv> ) ); export default class Demo extends React.PureComponent { constructor(props) { super(props); this.state = { data: appointments, mainResourceName: 'members', resources: [ { fieldName: 'location', title: 'Location', instances: [ { id: 'Room 1', text: 'Room 1' }, { id: 'Room 2', text: 'Room 2' }, { id: 'Room 3', text: 'Room 3' }, { id: 'Room 4', text: 'Room 4' }, { id: 'Room 5', text: 'Room 5' }, ], }, { fieldName: 'members', title: 'Members', allowMultiple: true, instances: [ { id: 1, text: 'Andrew Glover' }, { id: 2, text: 'Arnie Schwartz' }, { id: 3, text: 'John Heart' }, { id: 4, text: 'Taylor Riley' }, { id: 5, text: 'Brad Farkus' }, ], }, ], }; this.changeMainResource = this.changeMainResource.bind(this); } const CalendarM =()=>{ return( changeMainResource(mainResourceName) { this.setState({ mainResourceName }); } render() { const { data, resources, mainResourceName } = this.state; return ( <React.Fragment> <ResourceSwitcher resources={resources} mainResourceName={mainResourceName} onChange={this.changeMainResource} /> <Paper> <Scheduler data={data} > <ViewState defaultCurrentDate="2018-06-27" /> <WeekView startDayHour={11.5} endDayHour={16} /> <Appointments /> <AppointmentTooltip /> <Resources data={resources} mainResourceName={mainResourceName} /> </Scheduler> </Paper> </React.Fragment> ); } } ) } export default CalendarM;
ChatGPT

It seems there are a few syntax errors and misplaced code blocks in your component. Let me correct it for you:

jsx
import * as React from 'react';
import { styled } from '@mui/material/styles';
import Paper from '@mui/material/Paper';
import { ViewState } from '@devexpress/dx-react-scheduler';
import {
  Scheduler,
  Resources,
  WeekView,
  Appointments,
  AppointmentTooltip,
} from '@devexpress/dx-react-scheduler-material-ui';
import Select from '@mui/material/Select';
import MenuItem from '@mui/material/MenuItem';

const PREFIX = 'Demo';

const classes = {
  container: `${PREFIX}-container`,
  text: `${PREFIX}-text`,
};

const StyledDiv = styled('div')(({ theme }) => ({
  [`&.${classes.container}`]: {
    display: 'flex',
    marginBottom: theme.spacing(2),
    justifyContent: 'flex-end',
  },
  [`& .${classes.text}`]: {
    ...theme.typography.h6,
    marginRight: theme.spacing(2),
  },
}));

const ResourceSwitcher = ({
  mainResourceName, onChange, resources,
}) => (
  <StyledDiv className={classes.container}>
    <div className={classes.text}>
      Main resource name:
    </div>
    <Select
      variant="standard"
      value={mainResourceName}
      onChange={e => onChange(e.target.value)}
    >
      {resources.map(resource => (
        <MenuItem key={resource.fieldName} value={resource.fieldName}>
          {resource.title}
        </MenuItem>
      ))}
    </Select>
  </StyledDiv>
);

class CalendarM extends React.PureComponent {
  constructor(props) {
    super(props);
    this.state = {
      data: appointments,
      mainResourceName: 'members',
      resources: [
        {
          fieldName: 'location',
          title: 'Location',
          instances: [
            { id: 'Room 1', text: 'Room 1' },
            { id: 'Room 2', text: 'Room 2' },
            { id: 'Room 3', text: 'Room 3' },
            { id: 'Room 4', text: 'Room 4' },
            { id: 'Room 5', text: 'Room 5' },
          ],
        },
        {
          fieldName: 'members',
          title: 'Members',
          allowMultiple: true,
          instances: [
            { id: 1, text: 'Andrew Glover' },
            { id: 2, text: 'Arnie Schwartz' },
            { id: 3, text: 'John Heart' },
            { id: 4, text: 'Taylor Riley' },
            { id: 5, text: 'Brad Farkus' },
          ],
        },
      ],
    };

    this.changeMainResource = this.changeMainResource.bind(this);
  }

  changeMainResource(mainResourceName) {
    this.setState({ mainResourceName });
  }

  render() {
    const { data, resources, mainResourceName } = this.state;

    return (
      <React.Fragment>
        <ResourceSwitcher
          resources={resources}
          mainResourceName={mainResourceName}
          onChange={this.changeMainResource}
        />

        <Paper>
          <Scheduler
            data={data}
          >
            <ViewState
              defaultCurrentDate="2018-06-27"
            />
            <WeekView
              startDayHour={11.5}
              endDayHour={16}
            />
            <Appointments />
            <AppointmentTooltip />
            <Resources
              data={resources}
              mainResourceName={mainResourceName}
            />
          </Scheduler>
        </Paper>
      </React.Fragment>
    );
  }
}

export default CalendarM;

Please make sure you have imported appointments or defined it within the component. Additionally, you may need to adjust the import paths according to your project setup.

2 / 2
ChatGPT

To resolve the error "Syncfusion is not defined", you need to make sure that the Syncfusion library is properly imported and accessible in your React application.

First, ensure that you have installed the necessary Syncfusion packages via npm or yarn. If you haven't already, you can install the required packages by running:

bash
npm install @syncfusion/ej2-react-schedule @syncfusion/ej2-base @syncfusion/ej2-dropdowns

or

sql
yarn add @syncfusion/ej2-react-schedule @syncfusion/ej2-base @syncfusion/ej2-dropdowns

After installing the packages, you need to import the necessary modules from Syncfusion and register the Syncfusion license provider. Modify your code as follows:

jsx
import * as ReactDOM from 'react-dom';
import * as React from 'react';
import { ScheduleComponent, ViewsDirective, ViewDirective, Day, Week, WorkWeek, Month, Inject } from '@syncfusion/ej2-react-schedule';
import { createElement } from '@syncfusion/ej2-base';
import { DropDownList } from '@syncfusion/ej2-dropdowns';
import { SyncfusionLicense } from '@syncfusion/ej2-base';

// Register Syncfusion license
SyncfusionLicense.registerLicense('Your Syncfusion license key');

const CalendarM = () => {
    const eventSettings = {};

    const onPopupOpen = (args) => {
        if (args.type === 'Editor') {
            if (!args.element.querySelector('.custom-field-row')) {
                let row = createElement('div', { className: 'custom-field-row' });
                let formElement = args.element.querySelector('.e-schedule-form');
                formElement.firstChild.insertBefore(row, formElement.firstChild.firstChild);
                let container = createElement('div', { className: 'custom-field-container' });
                let inputEle = createElement('input', {
                    className: 'e-field', attrs: { name: 'EventType' }
                });
                container.appendChild(inputEle);
                row.appendChild(container);
                let drowDownList = new DropDownList({
                    dataSource: [
                        { text: 'Public Event', value: 'public-event' },
                        { text: 'Maintenance', value: 'maintenance' },
                        { text: 'Commercial Event', value: 'commercial-event' },
                        { text: 'Family Event', value: 'family-event' }
                    ],
                    fields: { text: 'text', value: 'value' },
                    value: args.data.EventType,
                    floatLabelType: 'Always', placeholder: 'Event Type'
                });
                drowDownList.appendTo(inputEle);
                inputEle.setAttribute('name', 'EventType');
            }
        }
    };

    return (
        <ScheduleComponent width='100%' height='550px' selectedDate={new Date(2018, 1, 15)} eventSettings={eventSettings} popupOpen={onPopupOpen}>
            <ViewsDirective>
                <ViewDirective option='Day' />
                <ViewDirective option='Week' />
                <ViewDirective option='WorkWeek' />
                <ViewDirective option='Month' />
            </ViewsDirective>
            <Inject services={[Day, Week, WorkWeek, Month]} />
        </ScheduleComponent>
    );
};

export default CalendarM;

Make sure to replace 'Your Syncfusion license key' with your actual Syncfusion license key. This should resolve the "Syncfusion is not defined" error.

You
export 'SyncfusionLicense' (imported as 'SyncfusionLicense') was not found in '@syncfusion/ej2-base' (possible exports: Ajax, Animation, Base, Browser, ChildProperty, Collection, CollectionFactory, Complex, ComplexFactory, Component, CreateBuilder, Draggable, Droppable, Event, EventHandler, Fetch, GlobalAnimationMode, HijriParser, Internationalization, IntlBase, KeyboardEvents, L10n, ModuleLoader, NotifyPropertyChanges, Observer, Position, Property, SanitizeHtmlHelper, SwipeSettings, Touch, addClass, addInstance, animationMode, append, attributes, blazorCultureFormats, blazorTemplates, classList, cldrData, cloneNode, closest, compareElementParent, compile, componentList, containerObject, containsClass, createElement, createInstance, createLicenseOverlay, debounce, defaultCulture, defaultCurrencyCode, deleteObject, detach, disableBlazorMode, enableBlazorMode, enableRipple, enableRtl, enableVersionBasedPersistence, extend, formatUnit, getAttributeOrDefault, getComponent, getDefaultDateObject, getElement, getEnumValue, getInstance, getNumberDependable, getNumericObject, getRandomId, getTemplateEngine, getUniqueID, getValue, getVersion, includeInnerHTML, initializeCSPTemplate, isBlazor, isNullOrUndefined, isObject, isObjectArray, isRippleEnabled, isUndefined, isVisible, loadCldr, matches, merge, onIntlChange, prepend, print, proxyToRaw, queryParams, registerLicense, remove, removeChildInstance, removeClass, resetBlazorTemplate, rightToLeft, rippleEffect, select, selectAll, setCulture, setCurrencyCode, setGlobalAnimation, setImmediate, setProxyToRaw, setStyleAttribute, setTemplateEngine, setValue, siblings, throwError, uniqueID, updateBlazorTemplate, validateLicense, versionBasedStatePersistence) [0] [0] webpack compiled with 1 error and 1 warning
ChatGPT

It seems that the SyncfusionLicense object is not exported from @syncfusion/ej2-base. Instead, you should import and use the registerLicense function directly. Here's the corrected import statement and usage:

javascript
import * as ReactDOM from 'react-dom';
import * as React from 'react';
import { ScheduleComponent, ViewsDirective, ViewDirective, Day, Week, WorkWeek, Month, Inject } from '@syncfusion/ej2-react-schedule';
import { createElement } from '@syncfusion/ej2-base';
import { DropDownList } from '@syncfusion/ej2-dropdowns';

// Import Syncfusion license registration function directly
import { registerLicense } from '@syncfusion/ej2-base';

// Register Syncfusion license
registerLicense('Your Syncfusion license key');

const CalendarM = () => {
    const eventSettings = {};

    const onPopupOpen = (args) => {
        if (args.type === 'Editor') {
            if (!args.element.querySelector('.custom-field-row')) {
                let row = createElement('div', { className: 'custom-field-row' });
                let formElement = args.element.querySelector('.e-schedule-form');
                formElement.firstChild.insertBefore(row, formElement.firstChild.firstChild);
                let container = createElement('div', { className: 'custom-field-container' });
                let inputEle = createElement('input', {
                    className: 'e-field', attrs: { name: 'EventType' }
                });
                container.appendChild(inputEle);
                row.appendChild(container);
                let drowDownList = new DropDownList({
                    dataSource: [
                        { text: 'Public Event', value: 'public-event' },
                        { text: 'Maintenance', value: 'maintenance' },
                        { text: 'Commercial Event', value: 'commercial-event' },
                        { text: 'Family Event', value: 'family-event' }
                    ],
                    fields: { text: 'text', value: 'value' },
                    value: args.data.EventType,
                    floatLabelType: 'Always', placeholder: 'Event Type'
                });
                drowDownList.appendTo(inputEle);
                inputEle.setAttribute('name', 'EventType');
            }
        }
    };

    return (
        <ScheduleComponent width='100%' height='550px' selectedDate={new Date(2018, 1, 15)} eventSettings={eventSettings} popupOpen={onPopupOpen}>
            <ViewsDirective>
                <ViewDirective option='Day' />
                <ViewDirective option='Week' />
                <ViewDirective option='WorkWeek' />
                <ViewDirective option='Month' />
            </ViewsDirective>
            <Inject services={[Day, Week, WorkWeek, Month]} />
        </ScheduleComponent>
    );
};

export default CalendarM;

Make sure to replace 'Your Syncfusion license key' with your actual Syncfusion license key. This should resolve the issue with the SyncfusionLicense not being found.

formElement.firstChild.insertBefore(row, formElement.firstChild.firstChild); let container = createElement('div', { className: 'custom-field-container' }); let inputEle = createElement('input', { className: 'e-field', attrs: { name: 'EventType' } });
